awd_titl_txt: University of Maryland Eastern Shore REU in Marine and Estuarine Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Maryland Eastern Shore, located in Princess Anne, MD, will support the training of 8 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2018- 2020.  The scientific focus of the REU program is on marine and estuarine science, particularly the ecology of coastal rivers, lagoons and estuaries in Maryland.  Students will have opportunities to work in various research areas such as the population dynamics of fish and macroinvertebrates, marine microbiology and parasitology, molecular biology and genetics, marine botany, environmental chemistry, and ecotoxicology.  Students will participate in workshops and seminars to teach them how to design field and laboratory research projects, collect and analyze data, and effectively present their results orally, in poster form, and in writing. They will receive training on ethics/responsible conduct of research, and complete surveys to enable us to assess the program.  Students will also go on field trips to familiarize themselves with the environment as well as the conservation and restoration projects in the Delmarva Peninsula.  Recruitment will target rising sophomores and rising juniors, particularly those belonging to underrepresented minority groups.  Completed on-line application forms will be reviewed, and students are selected based on their cumulative GPA (> 2.7 on a 4.0 maximum scale), interest in marine and environmental science, and strength of their letters of recommendation.

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.  

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.umes.edu/reu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Paulinus Chigbu at pchigbu@umes.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Margaret Sexton at masexton@umes.edu). This Site is supported by the Divisions of Biological Infrastructure in the Biological Sciences Directorate and the Oceanic Sciences in the Geosciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Rising sophomores and juniors, recruited from 24 institutions, participated in the 10-week summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the University of Maryland Eastern Shore (UMES). There were eight interns each in 2018 and 2019, and 9 interns in 2021 totaling twenty-five (25) students. They gained hands-on research experiences in marine and estuarine science, engaged in cohort building activities, and strengthened their analytical and communication skills by taking part in workshops and seminars. Interns received training and professional development through lectures on GIS, Proposal Writing, Experimental Design, Data Analyses, Marine Policy, Scientific Ethics, and Scientific Communication including effective oral presentation and poster preparation.  Each year, the students presented their research results orally and in form of posters to an audience comprised of faculty, students, and parents, at the end of program symposium. Several interns attended scientific meetings after the internship and made presentations.  The research experience program has helped to increase undergraduate student retention, academic performance, and the likelihood of success in graduate school.  Thus, the program has had a significant positive impact on the development and diversity of human resources in STEM, especially in marine and estuarine science. In particular, sixty percent (60%) of interns who took part in the program belonged to underrepresented minority (URM) groups.   

Using supplemental funds from NSF, we worked collaboratively with NEON staff and organized a 3-day virtual NEON-HBCU workshop that introduced HBCU faculty, researchers and graduate students to the use of NEON data and infrastructure. Prior to the workshop, we held a webinar entitled "An Introduction to the NEON Program", which was attended by 61 individuals including, 49 scientists and graduate students from 24 HBCUs.  Thereafter, we administered a survey to the participants to obtain information on their areas of expertise, prior experience with NEON and preferred coding language.  Twenty-three (23) scientists and graduate students completed the survey and registered for the NEON workshop. Of the 20 individuals who subsequently participated in the workshop, held from January 19 to 21, 2021, 12 were from HBCUs. The participants received information on how to access and use NEON data for research and classroom instructions.
